posts.cooked:
Here’s your cleaned-up paragraph, reformatted for clarity and correctness while preserving the original meaning:

Is there any reason you should continue maintaining our swerve code? I assume CTRE, which stands for Cross The Road Electronics, offers higher quality control and odometry systems compared to our current setup. Is there any reason why you wouldn’t consider switching? Regarding control, currently, we have drive states such as MANUAL, PATHFOLLOWING, and SEMIAUTO. Will switching to CTRE devices result in losing this level of control? Additionally, could a wrapper class help mitigate this concern? We have all CTR Edevices available.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked:
CTRE lists some features of their Swerve API at [Swerve Overview](https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/latest/docs/api-reference/mechanisms/swerve/swerve-overview.html). We used it this year and liked the built-in simulation and high-frequency odometry the most.

How is the control currently? We have drive states like MANUAL, PATHFOLLOWING, SEMIAUTO. Will I lose this control if using a wrapper class?

In the Swerve API, you have "Swerve Requests," similar to Phoenix 6 control. You can set different modes of control.

Here are reasons not to switch:
1. Device requirements: Replacing a failed Pigeon 2 gyro isn't possible
2. Code reference: Implementation is in C++, with limited public source
3. Flexibility: Some features aren't customizable, like automatic module removal
4. Log replay: Not as reliable as AdvantageKit
5. LabVIEW compatibility: Not supported

These factors are minor, making CTRE Swerve the best choice for existing hardware users.

link_counts.title: Comparison of Log Replay Tools | AdvantageKit

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked:
Another thing is log replay: CTR (Cross The Road Electronics) has their own log replay but it isn’t fully deterministic like AdvantageKit (see Comparison of Log Replay Tools for more details).

Just a quick point, you can use CTR-generated swerve code with Advantage Kit. Here is the documentation on how to do it.

The text is:  
At this point, I don’t think anyone should be writing their own swerve code. The CTRE code, specifically, is professionally written and maintained. It’s been tested by hundreds or even thousands of teams. Additionally, you’ll receive updates every season for the new seasonal libraries.  

Writing a solution with such extensive testing and troubleshooting is not feasible. Moreover, CTRE provides excellent support.  

My recommendation is to use their swerve code and focus on other areas to innovate. I don’t believe the effort is worth the investment. This advice applies to other platforms as well, including those where manufacturers provide their own code, such as YAGSL.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: I'm pretty sure that's not actually using the CTRE swerve code just using their project generator to create the config file that's then used by the AdvantageKit code.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
HLPryor thinks that everyone should stop writing their own swerve code. I believe his statement is too broad because it assumes people fully understand the circumstances, capabilities, and goals of every other team involved in FIRST Robotics Competition. 

I don't want to go into detail, but there are things one might want to do with Commercial, off-the-shelf swerve modules that the available libraries don't support.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
I'd recommend the AdvantageKit swerve maintained by 6328 which utilizes CTRE Generator to build configurations and constants. It is thoroughly documented on the Swerve template page. Teams that use it usually get it operational within an hour.

Features include:
- Easy setup with Tuner X swerve project generator
- High-frequency odometry
- CANivore time sync (for Phoenix Pro users)
- On-controller feedback loops
- Physics simulation
- Automated characterization routines
- Dashboard alerts for disconnected devices
- Pose estimator integration using standard FPGA timestamps
- Step-by-step setup and tuning instructions with a prebuilt AdvantageScope layout
- Deterministic replay with a guarantee of accuracy

As an experienced software professional with decades of experience, I couldn't disagree more.

If you're a team with massive software resources and mentors aiming for top-tier system performance, you aren't the right audience for solutions like middleware.

If you're part of the broader group leveraging tools such as Unity or Unreal, my stance remains unchanged.

Previously, I witnessed the same argument regarding game engines. While a few companies tailor their own solutions for specific reasons, the overwhelming majority benefit from existing frameworks like Unity or Unreal.

Most individuals operate under limited time and resources—unless they're tackling unique scenarios, attempting to solve problems from scratch is unwise. In general, seeking proven solutions is a sound approach.

Professionally, I've seen many companies succumb to the pitfalls of "not written here"—such issues almost always lead to failure. Opt for established, reliable solutions and keep progress on track.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: LPryor: If you are part of the vast majority of teams looking to leverage the capabilities of swerve then my statement stands. I agree. But you didn't say "the vast majority of teams." You said "anyone."

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked:
The CTREs Swerve API represents a significant enhancement to FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) software accessibility in recent years. Through Tuner X’s Swerve Project Generator, users are guided step-by-step on creating their Swerve drive components. Once a generated file is copied into a CTRE example or used directly from Tuner X, robust teleop driving is achieved. Characterization routines provided in both generated and example projects enable convenient setup of path generation software for effective path following. These features collectively provide not only baseline performance but also access to high-frequency odometry and simulation capabilities typically found in top-tier Swerve codebases. Additionally, the system integrates seamlessly with various path generation tools.

While the AdvantageKit Swerve Templates are highly recommended, they function as a replay framework rather than a Swerve library. For those seeking a Swerve library, CTRE offers an excellent solution. However, if replay functionality is desired, considering the AdvantageKit templates is advisable, though this introduces tradeoffs essential for deterministic replay.

The text is:  
Of the people asking this question my answer is generally the sane one given the teams that I work with that usually only have a single school teacher as a mentor. This answer maximizes their success. And I will continue to advise teams to not roll their own solutions.  

If you are in the top x% that need more power control and different use cases than the established middleware you usually aren’t the one asking. You have an informed opinion that’s backed up by sufficient resources to implement it.  

I use similar language in my profession in regards to middleware

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
We switched to Swerve this year and loved it. We made a few small adjustments, mainly tweaking the inputs from the controllers to achieve our preferred setup and incorporating additional telemetry features. Several aspects of Swerve stand out; for instance, parts of the logic were moved into a native layer, likely avoiding context switches in languages like Java.

From a learning perspective:
- Understanding how Swerve operates is valuable, and providing students with hands-on experience in implementing it is appropriate.
- In 2023, we utilized a modified version of 1678’s Swerve implementation. In 2024, we adopted the 254 setpoint generator approach. Both were effective.

Swerve code doesn't need to be overly complex. If desired, one could even write their own implementation, allowing flexibility in leveraging existing tools like WPIlib functions or onboard PID loops.

From a competitive standpoint:
- One mentor mentioned that 254 excels in embracing community-driven solutions.
- Following this approach, we incorporated more open-source software, built upon existing efforts, and enhanced our team's capabilities in automation and mechanisms like our elevator and wrist systems. Avoiding changes to drive or vision code enabled us to focus on other important areas, such as switching back to PhotonVision this year after developing a custom system.

Thank you for the insight; we will be going with the AdvantageKit Swerve, which we have been loving to replay this past year and plan to continue. If preferred, I am open to more comparisons, and if that's acceptable, I will consider switching again.
